title: partial views with options from session lead to JSON.stringify error (circular reference)
body:
Some steps to reproduce (in Express v2.5.8)

1) Create a new project with session support (what I did)
2) Add a route that saves something to req.session (Memory)
3) pass that value to res.render () to a view that contains a partial for the type saved in the session. In my example:

some code:

app.js

```
app.get('/', function (req, res) {
    req.session.user = {username:'dan', password:'ASDF'};
    res.render('index', { title: 'Express' });
});

app.get('/test', function (req, res) {
    res.render("test.jade", {title:'test', user:req.session.user});
});
```

test.jade

```
p User details:
!= partial('user', user)
```

_user.partial

```
p User Partial : #{user.username}, - #{user.password}
```

Initially, I got the following when trying to render the view, test.jade: 

```
node.js:201
        throw e; // process.nextTick error, or 'error' event on first tick
          ^
TypeError: Converting circular structure to JSON
    at Object.stringify (native)
    at Array.0 (/home/dan/development/aqp/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/middleware/session    /memory.js:77:31)
    at EventEmitter._tickCallback (node.js:192:40)
```

after some digging, I found that I narrowed this down to renderPartial() in express/lib/view.js.

The problem, as I understand it, is that because parentLocals (in this case the session?) appears to be utils.union()'ed with the partial's object, user, causing a circular reference.

I am willing to admit that I am pretty new to node.js in general, so I could really just be using the tools wrong.

title: Support PURGE request method.
body: Following my report of https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/2775, PURGE request supported has been added to node.js. In order to be usable with Express, the method needs to be added to lib/router/methods.js.

title: Support PURGE request method.
body: Following my report of https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/2775, PURGE request supported has been added to node.js. In order to be usable with Express, the method needs to be added to lib/router/methods.js.

app.configure('production', function() {});

title: Object prototype compatibility...
Generated app doesn't work with "npm start" command
body:
A new express application generated with "express MyApp" generates an "app.js" file.

NPM expects to see a file named "server.js" for use with the "npm start" command.

Is there a reason that express uses a different filename? Changing the generated filename to "server.js" would make it easier for people to get started with express and npm.

Express 2.5.8, NPM 1.1.1

title: req.accepts: */* wildcard fix
body:
Look for `*/*` anywhere in the Accept header instead of only supporting it when it's the exact value of the header.

IE8 sends:

```
Accept: image/gif, image/jpeg, image/pjpeg, image/pjpeg, application/x-shockwave-flash, application/x-ms-application, application/x-ms-xbap, application/vnd.ms-xpsdocument, application/xaml+xml, */*
```

for which `req.accepts('html')` returned `false`.

This bug doesn't exist on the master branch.

title: Problems setting server
sessionStore deletion, server.request middleware call
body:
So I've been trying to figure this out for a few hours, forgive my naivete.

When using connect's [MemoryStore](http://www.senchalabs.org/connect/middleware-session-memory.html), (yeh, yeh I should be using redis, this is educational only.) Where is the Session stored?

If you don't assign a variable to it... and allow Express to initialize the default MemoryStore

```
app.use(express.session({ secret: "keyboard cat" }));
```

How do you access the _MemoryStore_ ? Anything like, _server.routes.session.store_ ?

I know you can access it with _req.sessionStore_, but I'm trying to access it with only the _server_ variable. So my follow-up question is how do you simulate a request, or does Express have anyway to do "fake" requests? Like...

```
server.runFake(function(req, res){
req.blah  // Do some req/res stuff
console.log(res...)
});

// ...or...

console.log(server.request)  // Request object ?
console.log(server.response)  // Response object ?

```

---

Basically, must I have to do something like...

``` javascript
server = express.createServer({...})

server.get('/delete', function(req, res){
 req.sessionStore.clear()
});

require('superagent').get('http://localhost:3000/delete')
```

just to clear the sessions, with default _MemoryStore_, or is there a better way?

Thank You!

title: Added the ability to force the install of express scaffolding to a non-empty directory.
body:
I have used this to successfully install scaffolding using a local copy (non-global) of express into the same directory that express was installed from. Cloud9 does not give you the opportunity to say yes to the empty directory warning, so this was used as a workaround.

```
npm install express
node node_modules/express/bin/express -f
```

title: bug with leading slash
body:
squogre:~:% telnet localhost 3003
Trying 127.0.0.1...
Connected to localhost.
Escape character is '^]'.
GET http://example.com/test.html HTTP/1.0

HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found
X-Powered-By: Express
Content-Type: text/plain
Connection: close

Cannot GET /http://example.com/test.html
Connection closed by foreign host.

---

As you can see, when URI is full URL, Express adds extra slash before http in `request.url` despite the fact that is it already correct URL.

I was trying to write a proxy server and for a proxy such requests are quite common. 

I use latest version from git, and server was something simple like that:

```
app = require('express')();
app.listen(3003);
app.use (req,res,next) -> console.log(req.url); next()
```

title: [2.x] Do not to call `app.address()` before `listening` event
body:
Not sure if you still take pull requests for `2.x`, but:

According to joyent/node@d3f6b094c71a8d2c78dc6cd8bb50b01db6d38e27,
call to `net.Server.address()` should happen only after `net.Server`
emits `listening` event.

Inheriting res.locals (3.x)
body:
So, I've written a middleware that does some cool stuff. 

And to organise my app nicely I separate some features in different apps which is hooked onto the _mother app_. And then the _mother app_ that sets things up for all the children apps.

So, for this reason I'd like a way to inherit the `res.locals`. Since everything added to `req` is passed on nicely, I at least, expected changes to `res` to work similar. 

Anyway I've written a little self contained example of what I'd like to work: https://gist.github.com/1767058

`npm install -g git://github.com/visionmedia/express.git jade && node test-express.js` should do the trick ;)

If there's a workaround to the current behaviour somehow that would be enough for me too.

title: Incompatible with Node.js>0.7.0
body: Seems unreasonable to me considering that it appears to work.

title: pin package versions
body: It would be nice to pin the package version in the dependencies (for connect and the others). This is important for deployment where you want to be sure the same versions are running on all your deployed systems. Using >= is not good since different library authors might have different ideas about what is a breaking change. It also causes a disconnect between potentially deployed versions (if you push out to a new system and a newer version of the dependent library is used).

title: Rewriting url
Error in req.query
body:
I have these routes:

app.get('/:collection', function (req, res) { res.send(req.query)})
app.get('/:collection/:id', function (req, res) { res.send(req.query)}) 

If I call http://localhost/myCollection/myId?limit=2 is returned { limit : '2' }
If I call http://localhost/myCollection/?limit=2 is returned { limit : '2' } 

However

If I call http://localhost/myCollection?limit=2 is returned { } 
The query ?limit=2 is not recognised.

Is this a Express bug?
How can I do this work correctly.

I am using Express 2.5.6 and Node 0.6.5.

Thanks.

Is there a better way to handle uncaught exception in the server-side and appropriately notify the hanging request with a 503 response.

In my case, what is happening is, the request which ended with an exception hangs until a timeout from the server. if there is a better way to handle such situations, it would be really great.

Any help is appreciated.
Thanks.

title: It looks like 'connect' methodOverride sets req.method='del' and express app routing uses 'delete'
added newline character check in url in response.redirect function
body:
currently express framework do not check for newline characters
it is vulnerable to http splitting attack

example:
start the test server https://gist.github.com/1654555

browse http://localhost:3000/?foo=bar%0D%0ASet-Cookie%3Aname%3Dvalue
you will be re redirected to another page and cookie will be set

title: Remove trailing slashes from install path
body:
Hi,

This is a small cosmetic change to the `express` script.

When you insert a trailing slash in the path to be used as install path, the trailing slash stays in the variable, resulting in double slashes when the subdirectories are being created. This is ugly and confusing in my opinion.

before:
![before](http://f.cl.ly/items/2x0u0L132716172Z1S08/Screen%20Shot%202012-01-15%20at%2019.25.04.png)

after:
![after](http://f.cl.ly/items/320x1i150s1m470I2O1z/Screen%20Shot%202012-01-15%20at%2019.24.30.png)

title: Can't access some headers from middleware
View cache shared among multiple server instances
body:
Multiple server instances share the same registered template engines cache (in lib/views/views.js). This seems a bug to me (or at least hugely counter-intuitive, each is calling it's own app.use()).

Minimum testcase:
https://gist.github.com/1742486f390b86d3bac2

title: In express 2.x, filename should be set on cached templates
body:
A cached template that relies on the filename local parameter will currently generate an error. This one-line patch fixes the issue.

This commit also eliminates whitespace at the end of lines in views.js. I have vim set up to do this upon save.

title: Gave the router a name.
body: All the other connect middlewares are named functions.

title: fn argument to res.render is unclear
Express 2.5.4 and Nodejs 0.4.12 Session Problem on WinXP
body:
I am not sure if I am the only one that got this error.
When using Windows7, Mac or Linux, things are ok, but when it comes to WinXP the session is not working correctly

This is a log when I do success authentication (using everyauth) on Windows 7

``` javascript
starting step - displayLogin
...finished step
starting step - displayLogin
...finished step
starting step - extractLoginPassword
...finished step
starting step - authenticate
authenticate
session.userDetail
{ id: 'Guest368',
  username: 'Guest368',
  displayname: 'Guest368',
  avatar: '/images/default_profile.jpg'}
...finished step
starting step - interpretUserOrErrors
...finished step
starting step - getSession
...finished step
starting step - addToSession
...finished step
starting step - respondToLoginSucceed
...finished step
starting step - respondToLoginFail
...finished step
c7c023b36ea3b433cc22f3989d64d3f4
Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2.25) Gecko/20111212 Firefox/3.6.25
session
{ lastAccess: 1325581410837,
  cookie: 
   { path: '/',
     httpOnly: true,
     _expires: Tue, 03 Jan 2012 13:03:30 GMT,
     originalMaxAge: 14400000 },
  flash: {},
  roomId: 'c7c023b36ea3b433cc22f3989d64d3f4',
  userDetail: 
   { id: 'Guest368',
     username: 'Guest368',
     displayname: 'Guest368',
     avatar: '/images/default_profile.jpg'},
  auth: { loggedIn: true } }
```

And this is a log when I did a success authentication (using everyauth) on WinXP

``` javascript
starting step - displayLogin
...finished step
starting step - extractLoginPassword
...finished step
starting step - authenticate
authenticate
session.userDetail
{ id: 'Guest714',
  username: 'Guest714',
  displayname: 'Guest714',
  avatar: '/images/default_profile.jpg'}
...finished step
starting step - interpretUserOrErrors
...finished step
starting step - getSession
...finished step
starting step - addToSession
...finished step
starting step - respondToLoginSucceed
...finished step
starting step - respondToLoginFail
...finished step
c7c023b36ea3b433cc22f3989d64d3f4
Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2.25) Gecko/20111212 Firefox/3.6.25
session
{ lastAccess: 1325581290940,
  cookie: 
   { path: '/',
     httpOnly: true,
     _expires: Tue, 03 Jan 2012 13:01:30 GMT,
     originalMaxAge: 14400000 },
  roomId: 'c7c023b36ea3b433cc22f3989d64d3f4' }
```

With the same process and same configuration (Firefox 3.6, Firefox 9, Chrome 15,16, IE8,9, using RedisStore), Express Session on WinXP is totally different than the session on Windows 7. Although WinXP is super old, but there are still many WinXP users, and I have to support it.

title: express(1) issue on 0.4.x
body:
I have this problem when using expressjs 2.5.3 with nodejs 0.4.12 (2.5.2 does not have this error)

``` javascript
node.js:134
        throw e; // process.nextTick error, or 'error' event on first tick
        ^
TypeError: Object #<Object> has no method 'platform'
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/express/bin/express:34:25)
    at Module._compile (module.js:411:26)
    at Object..js (module.js:417:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:343:31)
    at Function._load (module.js:302:12)
    at Array.<anonymous> (module.js:430:10)
    at EventEmitter._tickCallback (node.js:126:26)
```
